<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">

<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>I promise this wasn’t planned (because we aren’t that organized), but this Sunday Edition turned out to be a love letter to the city of Atlanta, home to our Icebreakers guest Kat Cole, the subject of our news analysis section, and featured in our Open House listing.<strong></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If you don't live there, perhaps your experience of Atlanta is limited to sprinting halfway across the airport to catch a connecting flight on Delta. <strong></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But outside the airport walls, Atlanta has been a remarkable success story. My urban studies professor loved to point out that in 1950, Atlanta and Birmingham, AL, had roughly the same population. That’s...not even remotely the case now, with Atlanta exploding in size and becoming one of the most dynamic cities in the US.<strong></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So I hope you enjoy our first-ever “loosely themed” Sunday Edition. Which city should we feature next? I’m taking requests.*<strong></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">*Sorry Matty, Lincoln, Nebraska, isn't on the shortlist.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">—Neal Freyman<strong></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500"></p>
</div>

</tr>

</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With...Kat Cole, General Business All-Star
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/17/icebreakers-withkat-cole?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Kat Cole headshot" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83NDY0L2thdF9jb2xlX2hlYWRzaG90LmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Brigade Publicity</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If <a href="https://clubhouse.com/@kat?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Kat Cole</a> wasn’t on the next all-civilian space flight, it would actually surprise us—she’s<em> </em>always looking for the next big thing. At Hooters, she climbed the ranks from part-time hostess to company executive. Then, she joined Focus Brands, the parent company of Cinnabon, Auntie Anne’s, and other chains, where she became President and COO. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">These days, you can find her serving on many corporate and nonprofit boards, advising young business leaders, and discussing leadership on the <a href="https://www.clubhouse.com/club/leadershiplab?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Leadership Lab</a> on Clubhouse.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We talked to Kat about everything we could possibly squeeze in.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Do you own any NFTs?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Of course. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>And what attracted you to the space? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I fell in love with the energy and the opportunity. As a brand person, my brain immediately went to: Holy moly, this is really going to expand the ecosystem of IP and redefine the definition of a brand. And so my business brain, my branding brain, was really energized by the emergence of NFTs. Then I got connected in a human sense because we were having these conversations in rooms in Clubhouse. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You were at Hooters for 15 years and then Focus Brands for 10 years. That’s longer than most young people expect to stay at a company. Are they too quick to rush to new jobs? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">No, I don’t think they’re too quick. What I think people might miss about my two long stints at the same parent enterprise is I was in super high-growth companies, and so really I was running multiple different companies—I just didn’t have to leave the entity to do it. At Hooters, I was a hostess for six months, then I turned 18 and was a Hooters girl for another year, and even in that first year I started opening franchises. Then six months later when I was 20, I took a job at the corporate office. Two years later, I became director and oversaw a different department.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So there are benefits if you’re with a high-growth company. And that’s one of the things I always share with my story, when people are like, “Wow your career is so crazy and you got so many opportunities so young!” Yes, I learned over time to be a really thoughtful, caring, and driven leader, but you cannot remove a high-growth company from that equation. Like, I just got opportunities earlier than most people would.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If you were starting a company, would you make it fully remote? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Yes, I would make it fully remote, and I would put in some really killer and regular moments of in-person connection when it would be safe and possible. Probably every two months.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Is getting an MBA overrated or underrated? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Right now, it’s probably accurately rated. There is a healthy debate around it as there should be. But if you’re going to do the work of being in a cohort-based anything, a cohort-based course, a cohort-based MBA, make something of it. Keep the crew together, be the person who has the dinners and the Zooms. The value is in the community and the connection, not purely in the content. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You’ve seen how much automation has crept into the restaurant industry. Do you think your original position as a Hooters server will exist 10 years from now? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In 10 years I believe that people will increasingly want a high-tech front end, meaning ordering experience, and a high-touch back end, because orders get screwed up and you change your mind and it’s not what you wanted. And so the role of humans becomes more important in the service industry as automation comes into play.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">My husband and I just went on a mini-vacation; it was so amazing to be served. Just to have someone recommend drinks and to laugh with them and ask about the area, yet there were a couple moments where we wanted a quick meal where we ordered ahead and just wanted to go pick up the food.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So I do believe we’re going to see this separation between “fast” and “experience.” Where fast is valued, more roles will be replaced with automation. And where experience is valued, there still might be some automation in a piece of the production but that human element is going to be increasingly cherished. And people are going to pay a premium for it. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What has the better smell: Auntie Anne’s or Cinnabon?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">That is like asking me which of my children is my favorite. The aroma of Cinnabon makes my eyes roll back in my head. It’s indulgent, and I am satisfied almost just from that aroma. But the aroma of Auntie Anne’s makes me want to eat a pretzel, like, “Must. Eat. Pretzel.” The Cinnabon aroma is a bit more magic, and intoxicating, and Auntie Anne’s aroma is kind of like, “Take all my money.” </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity. </em></p>

<h1 class="sponsored-header__title" style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">

<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/13/future-business-travel-experts-morning-brew-hiltonand-youweigh" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Hilton" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://media2.morningbrew.com/uploads/placement/images/3867/1631578857-BusinessTravel_1667391589_Hilton.jpg">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;padding-left: 40px; margin-top:5px; margin-bottom:0px; line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>

<td class="sponsored-body" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0 40px 40px 40px">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">And let’s discuss the future of business travel. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Earlier this year we sent out a survey to you fine folks, and thousands of you responded to give us a very clear picture of just how much you miss those little chocolates hotels put on your pillow.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But we didn’t stop with you. We <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/13/future-business-travel-experts-morning-brew-hiltonand-youweigh" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">also interviewed</a> experts like Hilton’s Global Head of Marketing & Loyalty, Mark Weinstein, and (hi boss!) one of Morning Brew’s VPs, Elyssa Starkman.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/13/future-business-travel-experts-morning-brew-hiltonand-youweigh" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">our article with Hilton</a>, we discuss how much people are longing to get back on the road, how much amenities and perks really matter, how important in-person connections truly are, and how hotels are transforming and innovating for what’s to come.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">For instance, did you know WFH now stands for Work From Hotel? It’s an increasingly popular option for people who need some “me time” to get deals done.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/13/future-business-travel-experts-morning-brew-hiltonand-youweigh" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">So take a look at our article here</a>, and get prepared when it’s finally time to make your next sales call or in-person presentation.</p>

WORK LIFE
</p>

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
How to Ask for PTO
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/17/make-work?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>How do I ask for days off? I just started a new job and I feel guilty already asking for days off in the holiday season. We have an unlimited PTO policy. Will I be seen as not a hard worker or dependable?</strong><strong>—</strong><strong>Andrea, VA</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If soup, salad, and breadsticks have taught us anything, it’s that <em>unlimited</em> is typically good news. But while endless paid time off has become an increasingly common way for companies to regulate (or not) how much shine your OOO message gets, it also has the potential to create a minefield for those of us left to navigate the open-ended policy. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So let’s clear the table (you know, for more breadsticks): Assuming your company implemented the policy with good intentions, they’ve empowered you to determine how much time off you can realistically take without compromising your work—and while I’d recommend a more modest approach until you get a feel for where that line is, I don’t think a few days off during the holidays is an unreasonable place to start.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">WRT the asking, my mother always insisted on doing so nicely—although, come to think of it, she never did get a day off. It’s a good move to ask your manager if they have any preferences. Perhaps they’d appreciate you clearing dates with them before submitting to HR or blocking off your calendar. Still feeling anxious about the lack of parameters? Try asking about the <em>minimum </em>amount of PTO they would expect you to take. That way, you have an “approved” baseline to start from. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Like your brunch beverage of choice, bottomless PTO can be a pretty sweet menu item if done right. Yet, research suggests that employees who are offered unlimited time off actually use <em>fewer </em>days on average than those with a fixed amount—that’s a recipe for burnout. One thing that’s not unlimited is your mental and physical health, so don’t cheat yourself out of the time you need to properly recharge.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You Light Up My (Zoom) Life</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Last week, we asked Brew readers to chip in with advice for Brandon, whose office lacks the natural light needed to look his best on Zoom. While <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/reviews/best-ring-lights/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ring lights</a> won the day, Christina from Charlotte offered her own luminous perspective: </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">“Be your own light! If your personality shines, there’s no need for that ring light, people will immediately know it’s you.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Write in here</em></a><em>. </em><em>And coming soon...HR Brew. Be one of the </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24747517.1107/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2hyL3N1YnNjcmliZT91dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1jcm9zc3Byb21vJnV0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1ocl9pbl9tb3JuaW5nYnJld18wODE0MjE/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B7b0506f5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>first subscribers</em></a><em> to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources.</em></p>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>

</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
A Tech Hub Rises Among the Peach Orchards
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/17/atlanta-tech-hub-rises-among-peach-orchards?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Atlanta skyline" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83NDcxL2F0bGFudGFfc2t5bGluZS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Jose Fuste Raga/Getty Images</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Turns out, your city doesn’t need a tweeting mayor, beaches, or a Will Smith song to be considered the next hot region for tech.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">A recent string of deals has put Atlanta on the map as a growing power player in the US technology industry. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>The big one: </strong>Atlanta-based email marketing company Mailchimp was <a href="https://www.ajc.com/news/mailchimps-12b-sale-shows-atlantas-tech-mettle/V2JIV5K3AFB43N46QDZDZGUMNM/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sold to Intuit</a>, the maker of TurboTax, for $12 billion last week—the largest ever deal for a homegrown tech company. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In other Atlanta tech deals last week... </p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1">
<span>Goldman Sachs acquired </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/goldman-sachs-buy-lender-greensky-224-billion-deal-2021-09-15/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">GreenSky</a></span><span>, a fintech platform focused on home improvement loans, for $2.2 billion.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1">
<span>Logistics startup Stord became a logistics </span><span><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2021/09/14/logistics-startup-stord-raises-90m-in-kleiner-perkins-led-round-becomes-a-unicorn-and-acquires-another-company/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unicorn</a></span><span> after raising money at a valuation of $1.1 billion.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If Atlantans are a little reluctant to beat their chests, it’s because the city was considered a <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2021/05/02/how-did-atlanta-become-a-top-breeding-ground-for-billion-dollar-startups-in-the-southeast/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rising star in tech</a> several decades ago. In 1996, the city hosted the Summer Olympics, raising its profile around the globe. Local telecom and networking companies boomed with all the enthusiasm of the dot-com era. We all know how that turned out, though.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">The renaissance</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Following the dot-com bust, a new class of startups emerged, including familiar names Mailchimp, Kabbage (acquired by American Express), and Calendly. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Now, Atlanta is in a strong position to make further gains. It has one of the busiest airports in the US, Hartsfield-Jackson, huge corporations including Home Depot and Delta Air Lines, leading research institutions like Georgia Tech, and perhaps most importantly, loads of computer science and engineering talent—especially Black talent.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>The city is home to a cluster of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), including Clark Atlanta University, Morehouse College, and Spelman College. </span></li>
<li aria-level="1">
<span>Roughly 36% of Atlanta's tech workforce is either </span><span><a href="https://www.ajc.com/news/tech-talent-atlanta-improves-but-rivals-close-behind/MMLUA46ABJH5JDGSETPJVCGF2I/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Black or Hispanic</a></span><span>, second only to San Antonio. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Tech companies that have pledged to increase diversity in their workforces are <a href="https://www.ajc.com/news/west-coast-heads-east-atlantas-black-talent-lures-tech-titans/TTOKO3AH6RGNLITODD2VVY6MJU/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">eyeing</a> Atlanta’s Black engineering talent. Microsoft will hire 1,500 people at its new Atlanta office, Apple is partnering on a $50 million tech center, and Airbnb, explicitly citing the prevalence of Black talent in Atlanta, also plans to open a hub in the city.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Zoom out: </strong>While receiving $3.1 billion in venture funding in H1 2021, a record for the city, Atlanta is still a small fish in the tech pond (Silicon Valley, by comparison, attracted $48.9 billion in venture capital). Talented people are still leaving for better opportunities on the West Coast, and Atlanta faces growing competition from other Southeast cities, like Charlotte and Nashville. <em>–NF</em></p>

<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Open House
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that has an extensive tracking system for gaudy decor of Southern rich people. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/64k4YePGjFkuwrZiye/giphy.gif?cid=790b7611a8e365e658dccca54628e75176d634bfbf2edeff&rid=giphy.gif&ct=g" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="6 bed, 6 bath home in Atlanta, Georgia" data-source="Zillow" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Zillow</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">By now you know we can’t resist a McMansion. So let’s head to Atlanta, GA, (love a themed newsletter) for today’s <a href="https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/4064-Lyon-Blvd-SW-Atlanta-GA-30331/65461055_zpid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">early 2000s nightmare</a>. The only thing scarier than this 7,368 square-foot home attempting to cosplay as a castle is its obsession with columns. Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>6 beds, 6 baths</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Giant tub</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Lots of curved seating arrangements</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Fancy staircase, perfect for descending</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much for what would never be considered “Southern Charm”? Scroll to the bottom of the newsletter to find out.</p>

</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">1. Why there’s no such thing as the mind and nothing is mental. (<a href="https://aeon.co/essays/why-theres-no-such-thing-as-the-mind-and-nothing-is-mental?utm_source=nextdraft&utm_medium=email" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Aeon</a>)<br>2. The question Michael K. Williams asked before every season of <em>The Wire. </em>(<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/12/opinion/michael-k-williams-david-simon-the-wire.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">New York Times</a>)<br>3. (<a href="https://www.gawker.com/media/dear-prudie-it-was-me-all-along?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Gawker</a>)<br>4. An excerpt from a new biography on Peter Thiel. (<a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2021-09-15/peter-thiel-gamed-silicon-valley-tech-trump-taxes-and-politics?srnd=premium" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bloomberg Businessweek</a>)<br>5. Where Americans live. #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eI promise this wasn’t planned (because we aren’t that organized), but this Sunday Edition turned out to be a love letter to the city of Atlanta, home to our Icebreakers guest Kat Cole, the subject of our news analysis section, and featured in our Open House listing.\u003cstrong\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf you don't live there, perhaps your experience of Atlanta is limited to sprinting halfway across the airport to catch a connecting flight on Delta. \u003cstrong\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut outside the airport walls, Atlanta has been a remarkable success story. My urban studies professor loved to point out that in 1950, Atlanta and Birmingham, AL, had roughly the same population. That’s...not even remotely the case now, with Atlanta exploding in size and becoming one of the most dynamic cities in the US.\u003cstrong\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo I hope you enjoy our first-ever “loosely themed” Sunday Edition. Which city should we feature next? I’m taking requests.*\u003cstrong\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e*Sorry Matty, Lincoln, Nebraska, isn't on the shortlist.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003cstrong\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Kat Cole headshot\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83NDY0L2thdF9jb2xlX2hlYWRzaG90LmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eBrigade Publicity\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf \u003ca href=\"https://clubhouse.com/@kat?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eKat Cole\u003c/a\u003e wasn’t on the next all-civilian space flight, it would actually surprise us—she’s\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003ealways looking for the next big thing. At Hooters, she climbed the ranks from part-time hostess to company executive. Then, she joined Focus Brands, the parent company of Cinnabon, Auntie Anne’s, and other chains, where she became President and COO. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThese days, you can find her serving on many corporate and nonprofit boards, advising young business leaders, and discussing leadership on the \u003ca href=\"https://www.clubhouse.com/club/leadershiplab?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eLeadership Lab\u003c/a\u003e on Clubhouse.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe talked to Kat about everything we could possibly squeeze in.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDo you own any NFTs?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOf course. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAnd what attracted you to the space? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI fell in love with the energy and the opportunity. As a brand person, my brain immediately went to: Holy moly, this is really going to expand the ecosystem of IP and redefine the definition of a brand. And so my business brain, my branding brain, was really energized by the emergence of NFTs. Then I got connected in a human sense because we were having these conversations in rooms in Clubhouse. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou were at Hooters for 15 years and then Focus Brands for 10 years. That’s longer than most young people expect to stay at a company. Are they too quick to rush to new jobs? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNo, I don’t think they’re too quick. What I think people might miss about my two long stints at the same parent enterprise is I was in super high-growth companies, and so really I was running multiple different companies—I just didn’t have to leave the entity to do it. At Hooters, I was a hostess for six months, then I turned 18 and was a Hooters girl for another year, and even in that first year I started opening franchises. Then six months later when I was 20, I took a job at the corporate office. Two years later, I became director and oversaw a different department.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo there are benefits if you’re with a high-growth company. And that’s one of the things I always share with my story, when people are like, “Wow your career is so crazy and you got so many opportunities so young!” Yes, I learned over time to be a really thoughtful, caring, and driven leader, but you cannot remove a high-growth company from that equation. Like, I just got opportunities earlier than most people would.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you were starting a company, would you make it fully remote? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYes, I would make it fully remote, and I would put in some really killer and regular moments of in-person connection when it would be safe and possible. Probably every two months.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIs getting an MBA overrated or underrated? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eRight now, it’s probably accurately rated. There is a healthy debate around it as there should be. But if you’re going to do the work of being in a cohort-based anything, a cohort-based course, a cohort-based MBA, make something of it. Keep the crew together, be the person who has the dinners and the Zooms. The value is in the community and the connection, not purely in the content. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou’ve seen how much automation has crept into the restaurant industry. Do you think your original position as a Hooters server will exist 10 years from now? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn 10 years I believe that people will increasingly want a high-tech front end, meaning ordering experience, and a high-touch back end, because orders get screwed up and you change your mind and it’s not what you wanted. And so the role of humans becomes more important in the service industry as automation comes into play.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMy husband and I just went on a mini-vacation; it was so amazing to be served. Just to have someone recommend drinks and to laugh with them and ask about the area, yet there were a couple moments where we wanted a quick meal where we ordered ahead and just wanted to go pick up the food.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo I do believe we’re going to see this separation between “fast” and “experience.” Where fast is valued, more roles will be replaced with automation. And where experience is valued, there still might be some automation in a piece of the production but that human element is going to be increasingly cherished. And people are going to pay a premium for it. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat has the better smell: Auntie Anne’s or Cinnabon?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThat is like asking me which of my children is my favorite. The aroma of Cinnabon makes my eyes roll back in my head. It’s indulgent, and I am satisfied almost just from that aroma. But the aroma of Auntie Anne’s makes me want to eat a pretzel, like, “Must. Eat. Pretzel.” The Cinnabon aroma is a bit more magic, and intoxicating, and Auntie Anne’s aroma is kind of like, “Take all my money.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been edited and condensed for clarity. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F09%2F17%2Ficebreakers-withkat-cole\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; margin-top:5px; margin-bottom:0px; line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"sponsored-body\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0 40px 40px 40px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnd let’s discuss the future of business travel. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEarlier this year we sent out a survey to you fine folks, and thousands of you responded to give us a very clear picture of just how much you miss those little chocolates hotels put on your pillow.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut we didn’t stop with you. We \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/13/future-business-travel-experts-morning-brew-hiltonand-youweigh\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ealso interviewed\u003c/a\u003e experts like Hilton’s Global Head of Marketing \u0026 Loyalty, Mark Weinstein, and (hi boss!) one of Morning Brew’s VPs, Elyssa Starkman.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/13/future-business-travel-experts-morning-brew-hiltonand-youweigh\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eour article with Hilton\u003c/a\u003e, we discuss how much people are longing to get back on the road, how much amenities and perks really matter, how important in-person connections truly are, and how hotels are transforming and innovating for what’s to come.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eFor instance, did you know WFH now stands for Work From Hotel? It’s an increasingly popular option for people who need some “me time” to get deals done.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/13/future-business-travel-experts-morning-brew-hiltonand-youweigh\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eSo take a look at our article here\u003c/a\u003e, and get prepared when it’s finally time to make your next sales call or in-person presentation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- END SPONSORED SECTION --\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nHow to Ask for PTO\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/17/make-work?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make It Work logo\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow do I ask for days off? I just started a new job and I feel guilty already asking for days off in the holiday season. We have an unlimited PTO policy. Will I be seen as not a hard worker or dependable?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e—\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAndrea, VA\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf soup, salad, and breadsticks have taught us anything, it’s that \u003cem\u003eunlimited\u003c/em\u003e is typically good news. But while endless paid time off has become an increasingly common way for companies to regulate (or not) how much shine your OOO message gets, it also has the potential to create a minefield for those of us left to navigate the open-ended policy. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo let’s clear the table (you know, for more breadsticks): Assuming your company implemented the policy with good intentions, they’ve empowered you to determine how much time off you can realistically take without compromising your work—and while I’d recommend a more modest approach until you get a feel for where that line is, I don’t think a few days off during the holidays is an unreasonable place to start.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWRT the asking, my mother always insisted on doing so nicely—although, come to think of it, she never did get a day off. It’s a good move to ask your manager if they have any preferences. Perhaps they’d appreciate you clearing dates with them before submitting to HR or blocking off your calendar. Still feeling anxious about the lack of parameters? Try asking about the \u003cem\u003eminimum \u003c/em\u003eamount of PTO they would expect you to take. That way, you have an “approved” baseline to start from. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLike your brunch beverage of choice, bottomless PTO can be a pretty sweet menu item if done right. Yet, research suggests that employees who are offered unlimited time off actually use \u003cem\u003efewer \u003c/em\u003edays on average than those with a fixed amount—that’s a recipe for burnout. One thing that’s not unlimited is your mental and physical health, so don’t cheat yourself out of the time you need to properly recharge.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou Light Up My (Zoom) Life\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLast week, we asked Brew readers to chip in with advice for Brandon, whose office lacks the natural light needed to look his best on Zoom. While \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/reviews/best-ring-lights/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ering lights\u003c/a\u003e won the day, Christina from Charlotte offered her own luminous perspective: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e“Be your own light! If your personality shines, there’s no need for that ring light, people will immediately know it’s you.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a question about work you want to ask Shane? \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWrite in here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnd coming soon...HR Brew. beaches, or a Will Smith song to be considered the next hot region for tech.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eA recent string of deals has put Atlanta on the map as a growing power player in the US technology industry. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe big one: \u003c/strong\u003eAtlanta-based email marketing company Mailchimp was \u003ca href=\"https://www.ajc.com/news/mailchimps-12b-sale-shows-atlantas-tech-mettle/V2JIV5K3AFB43N46QDZDZGUMNM/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" company. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn other Atlanta tech deals last week... \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eGoldman Sachs acquired \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/goldman-sachs-buy-lender-greensky-224-billion-deal-2021-09-15/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGreenSky\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, a fintech platform focused on home improvement loans, for $2.2 billion.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eLogistics startup Stord became a logistics \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2021/09/14/logistics-startup-stord-raises-90m-in-kleiner-perkins-led-round-becomes-a-unicorn-and-acquires-another-company/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunicorn\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e after raising money at a valuation of $1.1 billion.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf Atlantans are a little reluctant to beat their chests, it’s because the city was considered a \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2021/05/02/how-did-atlanta-become-a-top-breeding-ground-for-billion-dollar-startups-in-the-southeast/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erising star in tech\u003c/a\u003e several decades ago. In 1996, the city hosted the Summer Olympics, raising its profile around the globe. Local telecom and networking companies boomed with all the enthusiasm of the dot-com era. We all know how that turned out, though.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eThe renaissance\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eFollowing the dot-com bust, a new class of startups emerged, including familiar names Mailchimp, Kabbage (acquired by American Express), and Calendly. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNow, Atlanta is in a strong position to make further gains. It has one of the busiest airports in the US, Hartsfield-Jackson, huge corporations including Home Depot and Delta Air Lines, leading research institutions like Georgia Tech, and perhaps most importantly, loads of computer science and engineering talent—especially Black talent.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe city is home to a cluster of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), including Clark Atlanta University, Morehouse College, and Spelman College. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eRoughly 36% of Atlanta's tech workforce is either \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ajc.com/news/tech-talent-atlanta-improves-but-rivals-close-behind/MMLUA46ABJH5JDGSETPJVCGF2I/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBlack or Hispanic\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, second only to San Antonio. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eTech companies that have pledged to increase diversity in their workforces are \u003ca href=\"https://www.ajc.com/news/west-coast-heads-east-atlantas-black-talent-lures-tech-titans/TTOKO3AH6RGNLITODD2VVY6MJU/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eeyeing\u003c/a\u003e Atlanta’s Black engineering talent. Microsoft will hire 1,500 people at its new Atlanta office, Apple is partnering on a $50 million tech center, and Airbnb, explicitly citing the prevalence of Black talent in Atlanta, also plans to open a hub in the city.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile receiving $3.1 billion in venture funding in H1 2021, a record for the city, Atlanta is still a small fish in the tech pond (Silicon Valley, by comparison, attracted $48.9 billion in venture capital). Talented people are still leaving for better opportunities on the West Coast, and Atlanta faces growing competition from other Southeast cities, like Charlotte and Nashville. \u003cem\u003e–NF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F09%2F17%2Fatlanta-tech-hub-rises-among-peach-orchards\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
